# Improving Unsupervised Constituency Parsing via Maximizing Semantic Information

yusuke@is.s.u-tokyo.ac.jp, danushka@liverpool.ac.uk

###### Abstract

Unsupervised constituency parsers organize phrases within a sentence into a tree-shaped syntactic constituent structure that reflects the organization of sentence semantics.
However, the traditional objective of maximizing sentence log-likelihood (LL) does not explicitly account for the close relationship between the constituent structure and the semantics, resulting in a weak correlation between LL values and parsing accuracy.
In this paper, we introduce a novel objective for training unsupervised parsers: maximizing the information between constituent structures and sentence semantics (SemInfo).
We introduce a bag-of-substrings model to represent the semantics and apply the probability-weighted information metric to estimate the SemInfo.
Additionally, we develop a Tree Conditional Random Field (TreeCRF)-based model to apply the SemInfo maximization objective to Probabilistic Context-Free Grammar (PCFG) induction, the state-of-the-art method for unsupervised constituency parsing.
Experiments demonstrate that SemInfo correlates more strongly with parsing accuracy than LL.
Our algorithm significantly enhances parsing accuracy by an average of 7.85 points across five PCFG variants and in four languages, achieving new state-of-the-art results in three of the four languages.

## 1 Introduction

Unsupervised constituency parsing is a syntactic task of organizing phrases of a sentence into a tree-shaped and unlabelled constituent structure without relying on any linguistic annotations (Klein & Manning, [2002](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib18 "")).
The constituent structure is a fundamental tool in analyzing sentence semantics (i.e., the meaning) (Carnie, [2007](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib6 ""); Steedman, [2000](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib33 "")) and can significantly improve performance for downstream Natural Language Processing systems, such as natural language inference (He et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib13 "")), machine translation (Xie & Xing, [2017](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib36 "")) and semantic role labeling (Chen et al., [2022](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib8 "")).
Each constituent in the structure corresponds to a meaningful substring in the sentence, which guides us to progressively construct the sentence semantics.
Figure [1](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#S1.F1 "Figure 1 ‚Ä£ 1 Introduction ‚Ä£ Improving Unsupervised Constituency Parsing via Maximizing Semantic Information") illustrates the progressive semantic construction of the sentence ‚ÄúJohn has been working on a theory until late night‚Äù.
This example demonstrates that _constituent substrings in the sentence carry significant semantic information_, illustrating an alignment between syntax and semantics.

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558/assets/x1.png)Figure 1: An illustration of the progressive semantics build-up in accordance with the constituent structure. The tree structure in the top-right shows the simplified constituent structure for illustration purposes. Constituent strings are highlighted in blue.

Maximizing sentence log-likelihood has traditionally been the primary training objective for unsupervised constituency parsers (Eisner, [2016](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib11 ""); Kim et al., [2019a](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib16 "")).
However, Log-Likelihood (LL), the objective function, does not explicitly factor in the syntax-semantics alignment.
This leads to a poor correlation between the LL value and the parsing accuracy, which we will discuss further in Section [5.3](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#S5.SS3 "5.3 SemInfo Strongly Correlates with Sentence-F1 ‚Ä£ 5 Experiment ‚Ä£ Improving Unsupervised Constituency Parsing via Maximizing Semantic Information").
As pointed out in previous research, training a Probabilistic Context-Free Grammar (PCFG) parser that outperforms trivial baselines with the LL maximization objective is challenging (Carroll & Charniak, [1992](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib7 ""); Kim et al., [2019a](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib16 "")).
Successful training commonly involves altering the LL maximization objective, such as imposing sparsity constraints (Cohen et al., [2008](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib10 ""); Johnson et al., [2007](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib15 "")) or heuristically estimating the LL value (Spitkovsky et al., [2010](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib32 "")).
Evidence suggests that the LL function might not provide robust information to distinguish between constituents and non-constituents, rendering LL an insufficient objective function for unsupervised parsing.

In this paper, we propose a novel objective for unsupervised constituency parsing: maximizing the semantic information that constituent structures carry.
We propose a novel method for measuring _SemInfo_, the information between constituent structures and sentence semantics.
Specifically, we introduce a bag-of-substrings model to represent the sentence semantics and quantify semantic information encoded in each substring using the probability-weighted information metric developed for bag-of-words models (Aizawa, [2003](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib1 "")).
We calculate the SemInfo value by aggregating the substring-semantic information associated with the constituent structure.
Experiments show a much stronger correlation between SemInfo and the parsing accuracy than the correlation between LL and the parsing accuracy, suggesting that SemInfo is an effective objective function for unsupervised constituency parsing.
In addition, we develop a Tree Conditional Random Field (TreeCRF)-based model to apply the SemInfo maximization objective to PCFG induction, the state-of-the-art method for unsupervised constituency parsing.
Experiments demonstrate that the SemInfo maximization objective improves the PCFG‚Äôs parsing accuracy by 7.85 points across five latest PCFG variants and in four languages.

Our main contributions are: (1) Proposing a novel method for estimating SemInfo, the information between constituent structures and sentence semantics. (2) Demonstrating a strong correlation between SemInfo values and parsing accuracy. (3) Developing a TreeCRF model to apply the SemInfo maximization objective to PCFG induction, significantly improving parsing accuracy and setting new state-of-the-art results in three of the four languages tested.

## 2 Background

The idea that constituent structures reflect the organization of sentence semantics is central to modern linguistic studies (Steedman, [2000](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib33 ""); Pollard & Sag, [1987](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib25 "")).
A constituent is a substring sùë†s in a sentence xùë•x that can function independently (Carnie, [2007](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib6 "")) and carries individual meaning (Heim & Kratzer, [1998](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib14 "")).

Previous research evaluates unsupervised constituency parsers using sentence-F1, the F1 score computed from the string collection representing the predicted structure and the collection representing the gold structure (Shen et al., [2017](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib27 "")).

## 3 SemInfo: A Metric of Information between Constituent Structures and Semantics

In this section, we introduce our estimation method of SemInfo, the information between constituent structures and sentence semantics.
We first introduce a bag-of-substrings model, representing the semantics of a sentence by examining whether substrings of the sentence would be _regenerated_ during a paraphrasing process.
We then apply the PWI (Aizawa, [2003](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib1 "")) metric to measure the substring-semantics information.
For a given constituent structure, we estimate its SemInfo value by aggregating the substring-semantics information associated with the structure.

## 4 SemInfo Maximization via TreeCRF Model

We apply the SemInfo maximization objective to PCFG induction models by maximizing Equation [13](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#S4.E13 "In 4 SemInfo Maximization via TreeCRF Model ‚Ä£ Improving Unsupervised Constituency Parsing via Maximizing Semantic Information").

We model the parser using the TreeCRF model derived from the TreeMBR decoding algorithm.
We choose the TreeCRF model because we can efficiently sample from the tree distribution and calculate the entropy.

## 5 Experiment

### 5.1 Experiment Setup

We evaluate the effect of the SemInfo maximization objective on five latest PCFG variants: Neural-PCFG (NPCFG), Compound-PCFG (CPCFG) (Kim et al., [2019a](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib16 "")), TNPCFG (Yang et al., [2021b](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib39 "")), Simple-NPCFG (SNPCFG), and Simple-CPCFG (SCPCFG) (Liu et al., [2023](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib20 "")).222Our implementation is based on the source code released by Yang et al. ( [2021b](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib39 "")) and Liu et al. ( [2023](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib20 ""))
SNPCFG and SCPCFG represent the current state-of-the-art for non-ensemble unsupervised constituency parsing.
We use 60 NTs for NPCFG and CPCFG, and 1024 NTs for TNPCFG, SNPCFG, and SCPCFG in our experiment.
We conduct the evaluations in four languages, namely English, Chinese, German, and French, as Liu et al. ( [2023](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib20 "")) did previously.
We use the Penn TreeBank (PTB) (Marcus et al., [1999](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib21 "")) for the English evaluation, the Chinese Treebank 5.1 (CTB) (Palmer et al., [2005](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib24 "")) for the Chinese evaluation, and the SPMRL dataset (Seddah et al., [2013](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib26 "")) for the German and French evaluation.
We adopt the standard data split for the PTB dataset,
using Sections 02-21 for training, Section 22 for validation, and Section 23 for testing (Kim et al., [2019a](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib16 "")).
We adopt the official data split for the CTB and SPMRL datasets.

Following Shen et al. ( [2017](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib27 "")), we train the PCFG induction model on raw text and evaluate its parsing performance using corpus-level sentence-F1 scores.
The corpus-level score is computed by averaging the sentence-F1 score across the entire corpus.
We evaluate the sentence-F1 score for sentences longer than two words and drop punctuation and trivial spans (i.e., sentence-level spans and spans with only one word).

Following Chen et al. ( [2024](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib9 "")), we use the gpt-4o-mini-2024-07-18 model as our paraphrasing model to facilitate multilingual experiments and apply normalization to the source sentence and the paraphrases.
We use eight semantic-preserving prompts for the paraphrasing model.333Detailed prompts are listed in Section [A.5](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#A1.SS5 "A.5 Paraphrasing prompts ‚Ä£ Appendix A Appendix ‚Ä£ Improving Unsupervised Constituency Parsing via Maximizing Semantic Information")
We apply the snowball stemmer (Bird & Loper, [2004](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib3 "")) to normalize the source sentence and its paraphrases before calculating the maximal substring frequency and the inverse document frequency.
We apply the log-normalization (Sparck Jones, [1972](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib30 "")) to the maximal substring frequency to avoid some high-frequency substrings dominating the SemInfo value.
We found that the log-normalization variant performs marginally but consistently better than the unnormalized variant in our preliminary experiment.

### 5.3 SemInfo Strongly Correlates with Sentence-F1

In this section, we evaluate two aspects of the SemInfo and LL functions: 1) Whether the function can accurately evaluate the model‚Äôs prediction. 2) Whether the function can approximately rank models in accordance with their performance.
We evaluate the two aspects using Spearman correlation (Spearman, [1904](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib31 "")), examining whether the objective function can rank good predictions/models higher than the bad ones.
We evaluate the prediction ranking capability using a sentence-level correlation and the model ranking capability using a corpus-level correlation.

#### 5.3.1 SemInfo is an Accurate Metric of Parsing Accuracy

The sentence-level correlation assesses the objective function‚Äôs capability to evaluate the model prediction accurately.
We independently train eight _identical_ PCFG models using the LL maximization objective.
Each model is trained with a unique random seed for 30k steps.
For every sentence, the eight models produce eight (sentence-F1, SemInfo, LL) tuples, which we use to calculate the sentence-level Spearman correlation coefficient.

Figure [4](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#S5.F4 "Figure 4 ‚Ä£ 5.3.1 SemInfo is an Accurate Metric of Parsing Accuracy ‚Ä£ 5.3 SemInfo Strongly Correlates with Sentence-F1 ‚Ä£ 5 Experiment ‚Ä£ Improving Unsupervised Constituency Parsing via Maximizing Semantic Information") illustrates the SemInfo-sentence-F1 correlation and the LL-sentence-F1 correlation using a random sentence in the English validation set.
We observed a strong positive correlation for the (SemInfo, sentence-F1) pairs but observed no positive correlation for the (LL, sentence-F1) pairs.
Table [2](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#S5.T2 "Table 2 ‚Ä£ 5.3.1 SemInfo is an Accurate Metric of Parsing Accuracy ‚Ä£ 5.3 SemInfo Strongly Correlates with Sentence-F1 ‚Ä£ 5 Experiment ‚Ä£ Improving Unsupervised Constituency Parsing via Maximizing Semantic Information") demonstrates the correlation in a more statistically reliable way.
We perform mean-aggregation on the sentence-level correlation coefficient using Fisher‚Äôs Z transformation (Fisher, [1915](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib12 "")).
Fisher‚Äôs Z transformation converts the correlation coefficient to a uni-variance space, reducing the negative impact caused by the skewness in the coefficient‚Äôs distribution(Silver & Dunlap, [1987](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib29 "")).
The aggregated coefficients for the SemInfo-sentence-F1 correlation range from 0.6-0.9, whereas the aggregated coefficients for the LL-sentence-F1 correlation center around 0.

The high SemInfo-sentence-F1 coefficient indicates that SemInfo can serve as an accurate metric of parsing accuracy.
The gap in correlation coefficients suggests that SemInfo might be a better objective function for unsupervised constituency parsing than LL.

## 6 Related works

Parsing with Substring Frequency To the best of our knowledge, Chen et al. ( [2024](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib9 "")) first found that the substring frequency calculated among paraphrases can be used to identify constituent structures.
We extend their findings, establishing a connection between semantic information and the frequency statistic.
We interpret the substring frequency as a term in the substring-semantics information and apply the substring-semantics information to improve PCFG induction.
Our method significantly outperforms theirs in three out of the four languages tested.

Parsing with PCFG
PCFG induction is a long-established (Klein & Manning, [2002](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib18 "")) and state-of-the-art (Liu et al., [2023](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib20 "")) approach for non-ensemble unsupervised constituency parsing.
Much research has dedicated to improving PCFG induction from the model perspective, such as scaling up the PCFG model (Yang et al., [2021b](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib39 ""); Liu et al., [2023](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib20 "")), integrating lexical information (Yang et al., [2021a](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib38 "")), and allowing PCFG rule probabilities to condition on sentence embeddings through variational inferences (Kim et al., [2019a](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib16 "")).
Our improvement is from the model optimization perspective and can be combined with the above efforts.
Our experiments validate the effectiveness of the SemInfo maximization objective in improving unlexicalized PCFGs.
The SemInfo maximization objective is also applicable to lexicalized PCFGs, which we leave to future work.

Parsing with SemanticsZhao & Titov ( [2020](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib41 "")) and Zhang et al. ( [2021](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib40 "")) have sought to improve PCFG induction by learning to identify visual features, maximizing the association between constituent structures and these visual features.
If we consider the visual features as semantic representations, their approach is effectively maximizing the semantic information of the constituent structure.
In comparison, our method shares the same underlying principle but represents the semantics with textual features.
Our method leverages large language models as semantic processors, utilizing their outstanding semantic processing capabilities (Minaee et al., [2024](https://ar5iv.org/html/2410.02558#bib.bib22 "")).
We believe that combining both textual and visual semantic representations presents a significant research direction for unsupervised parsing tasks.

## 7 Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed and validated a novel objective for unsupervised constituency parsing: maximizing the information between constituent structures and sentence semantics (SemInfo).
We developed a bag-of-substrings model to represent the semantics and applied the probability-weighted information metric to estimate the SemInfo.
We applied the SemInfo maximization objective by maximizing the expected SemInfo for a PCFG-based TreeCRF parser.
Experiments showed that SemInfo has a strong sentence-level correlation with sentence-F1 and that SemInfo maintains a consistent corpus-level correlation throughout the PCFG training process.
The strong sentence-level correlation indicates that SemInfo can serve as an accurate metric of parsing accuracy.
The consistent corpus-level correlation indicates that SemInfo can serve as a reliable training objective for unsupervised parsing.
As a result, SemInfo-trained PCFGs significantly outperformed LL-trained PCFGs across four languages and achieved new state-of-the-art results in three of them.
Our findings underscore the effectiveness of leveraging semantic information in unsupervised constituency parsing, paving the way for accurate semantically-informed unsupervised parsing methods.

1 Introduction.content:
Unsupervised constituency parsing is a syntactic task of organizing phrases of a sentence into a tree-shaped and unlabelled constituent structure without relying on any linguistic annotations (Klein & Manning, [2002]).
The constituent structure is a fundamental tool in analyzing sentence semantics (i.e., the meaning) (Carnie, [2007]; Steedman, [2000]) and can significantly improve performance for downstream Natural Language Processing systems, such as natural language inference (He et al., [2020]), machine translation (Xie & Xing, [2017]) and semantic role labeling (Chen et al., [2022]).
Each constituent in the structure corresponds to a meaningful substring in the sentence, which guides us to progressively construct the sentence semantics.
Figure [1]Figure 1 ‚Ä£ 1 Introduction ‚Ä£ Improving Unsupervised Constituency Parsing via Maximizing Semantic Information") illustrates the progressive semantic construction of the sentence ‚ÄúJohn has been working on a theory until late night‚Äù.
This example demonstrates that _constituent substrings in the sentence carry significant semantic information_, illustrating an alignment between syntax and semantics.

![Refer to caption]Figure 1: An illustration of the progressive semantics build-up in accordance with the constituent structure. The tree structure in the top-right shows the simplified constituent structure for illustration purposes. Constituent strings are highlighted in blue.

Maximizing sentence log-likelihood has traditionally been the primary training objective for unsupervised constituency parsers (Eisner, [2016]; Kim et al., [2019a]).
However, Log-Likelihood (LL), the objective function, does not explicitly factor in the syntax-semantics alignment.
This leads to a poor correlation between the LL value and the parsing accuracy, which we will discuss further in Section [5.3]SemInfo Strongly Correlates with Sentence-F1 ‚Ä£ 5 Experiment ‚Ä£ Improving Unsupervised Constituency Parsing via Maximizing Semantic Information").
As pointed out in previous research, training a Probabilistic Context-Free Grammar (PCFG) parser that outperforms trivial baselines with the LL maximization objective is challenging (Carroll & Charniak, [1992]; Kim et al., [2019a]).
Successful training commonly involves altering the LL maximization objective, such as imposing sparsity constraints (Cohen et al., [2008]; Johnson et al., [2007]) or heuristically estimating the LL value (Spitkovsky et al., [2010]).
Evidence suggests that the LL function might not provide robust information to distinguish between constituents and non-constituents, rendering LL an insufficient objective function for unsupervised parsing.

In this paper, we propose a novel objective for unsupervised constituency parsing: maximizing the semantic information that constituent structures carry.
We propose a novel method for measuring _SemInfo_, the information between constituent structures and sentence semantics.
Specifically, we introduce a bag-of-substrings model to represent the sentence semantics and quantify semantic information encoded in each substring using the probability-weighted information metric developed for bag-of-words models (Aizawa, [2003]).
We calculate the SemInfo value by aggregating the substring-semantic information associated with the constituent structure.
Experiments show a much stronger correlation between SemInfo and the parsing accuracy than the correlation between LL and the parsing accuracy, suggesting that SemInfo is an effective objective function for unsupervised constituency parsing.
In addition, we develop a Tree Conditional Random Field (TreeCRF)-based model to apply the SemInfo maximization objective to PCFG induction, the state-of-the-art method for unsupervised constituency parsing.
Experiments demonstrate that the SemInfo maximization objective improves the PCFG‚Äôs parsing accuracy by 7.85 points across five latest PCFG variants and in four languages.

Our main contributions are: (1) Proposing a novel method for estimating SemInfo, the information between constituent structures and sentence semantics. (2) Demonstrating a strong correlation between SemInfo values and parsing accuracy. (3) Developing a TreeCRF model to apply the SemInfo maximization objective to PCFG induction, significantly improving parsing accuracy and setting new state-of-the-art results in three of the four languages tested.

We first introduce a bag-of-substrings model, representing the semantics of a sentence by examining whether substrings of the sentence would be _regenerated_ during a paraphrasing process.
We then apply the PWI (Aizawa, [2003]) metric to measure the substring-semantics information.
For a given constituent structure, we estimate its SemInfo value by aggregating the substring-semantics information associated with the structure.

5 Experiment.content:
### 5.1 Experiment Setup

We evaluate the effect of the SemInfo maximization objective on five latest PCFG variants: Neural-PCFG (NPCFG), Compound-PCFG (CPCFG) (Kim et al., [2019a]), TNPCFG (Yang et al., [2021b]), Simple-NPCFG (SNPCFG), and Simple-CPCFG (SCPCFG) (Liu et al., [2023]).222Our implementation is based on the source code released by Yang et al. ( [2021b]) and Liu et al. ( [2023])
SNPCFG and SCPCFG represent the current state-of-the-art for non-ensemble unsupervised constituency parsing.
We use 60 NTs for NPCFG and CPCFG, and 1024 NTs for TNPCFG, SNPCFG, and SCPCFG in our experiment.
We conduct the evaluations in four languages, namely English, Chinese, German, and French, as Liu et al. ( [2023]) did previously.
We use the Penn TreeBank (PTB) (Marcus et al., [1999]) for the English evaluation, the Chinese Treebank 5.1 (CTB) (Palmer et al., [2005]) for the Chinese evaluation, and the SPMRL dataset (Seddah et al., [2013]) for the German and French evaluation.
We adopt the standard data split for the PTB dataset,
using Sections 02-21 for training, Section 22 for validation, and Section 23 for testing (Kim et al., [2019a]).
We adopt the official data split for the CTB and SPMRL datasets.

Following Shen et al. ( [2017]), we train the PCFG induction model on raw text and evaluate its parsing performance using corpus-level sentence-F1 scores.
The corpus-level score is computed by averaging the sentence-F1 score across the entire corpus.
We evaluate the sentence-F1 score for sentences longer than two words and drop punctuation and trivial spans (i.e., sentence-level spans and spans with only one word).

Following Chen et al. ( [2024]), we use the gpt-4o-mini-2024-07-18 model as our paraphrasing model to facilitate multilingual experiments and apply normalization to the source sentence and the paraphrases.
We use eight semantic-preserving prompts for the paraphrasing model.333Detailed prompts are listed in Section [A.5]A.5 Paraphrasing prompts ‚Ä£ Appendix A Appendix ‚Ä£ Improving Unsupervised Constituency Parsing via Maximizing Semantic Information")
We apply the snowball stemmer (Bird & Loper, [2004]) to normalize the source sentence and its paraphrases before calculating the maximal substring frequency and the inverse document frequency.
We apply the log-normalization (Sparck Jones, [1972]) to the maximal substring frequency to avoid some high-frequency substrings dominating the SemInfo value.
We found that the log-normalization variant performs marginally but consistently better than the unnormalized variant in our preliminary experiment.
The application of log-normalization is aligned with the theoretical framework of Aizawa ( [2003])).

### 5.3 SemInfo Strongly Correlates with Sentence-F1

In this section, we evaluate two aspects of the SemInfo and LL functions: 1) Whether the function can accurately evaluate the model‚Äôs prediction. 2) Whether the function can approximately rank models in accordance with their performance.
We evaluate the two aspects using Spearman correlation (Spearman, [1904]), examining whether the objective function can rank good predictions/models higher than the bad ones.
We evaluate the prediction ranking capability using a sentence-level correlation and the model ranking capability using a corpus-level correlation.

#### 5.3.1 SemInfo is an Accurate Metric of Parsing Accuracy

The sentence-level correlation assesses the objective function‚Äôs capability to evaluate the model prediction accurately.
We independently train eight _identical_ PCFG models using the LL maximization objective.
Each model is trained with a unique random seed for 30k steps.
For every sentence, the eight models produce eight (sentence-F1, SemInfo, LL) tuples, which we use to calculate the sentence-level Spearman correlation coefficient.

6 Related works.content:
Parsing with Substring Frequency To the best of our knowledge, Chen et al. ( [2024]) first found that the substring frequency calculated among paraphrases can be used to identify constituent structures.
We extend their findings, establishing a connection between semantic information and the frequency statistic.
We interpret the substring frequency as a term in the substring-semantics information and apply the substring-semantics information to improve PCFG induction.
Our method significantly outperforms theirs in three out of the four languages tested.

Parsing with PCFG
PCFG induction is a long-established (Klein & Manning, [2002]) and state-of-the-art (Liu et al., [2023]) approach for non-ensemble unsupervised constituency parsing.
Much research has dedicated to improving PCFG induction from the model perspective, such as scaling up the PCFG model (Yang et al., [2021b]; Liu et al., [2023]), integrating lexical information (Yang et al., [2021a]), and allowing PCFG rule probabilities to condition on sentence embeddings through variational inferences (Kim et al., [2019a]).
Our improvement is from the model optimization perspective and can be combined with the above efforts.
Our experiments validate the effectiveness of the SemInfo maximization objective in improving unlexicalized PCFGs.
The SemInfo maximization objective is also applicable to lexicalized PCFGs, which we leave to future work.

Parsing with SemanticsZhao & Titov ( [2020])) and Zhang et al. ( [2021]) have sought to improve PCFG induction by learning to identify visual features, maximizing the association between constituent structures and these visual features.
If we consider the visual features as semantic representations, their approach is effectively maximizing the semantic information of the constituent structure.
In comparison, our method shares the same underlying principle but represents the semantics with textual features.
Our method leverages large language models as semantic processors, utilizing their outstanding semantic processing capabilities (Minaee et al., [2024]).
We believe that combining both textual and visual semantic representations presents a significant research direction for unsupervised parsing tasks.

7 Conclusion.content:
In this paper, we proposed and validated a novel objective for unsupervised constituency parsing: maximizing the information between constituent structures and sentence semantics (SemInfo).
We developed a bag-of-substrings model to represent the semantics and applied the probability-weighted information metric to estimate the SemInfo.
We applied the SemInfo maximization objective by maximizing the expected SemInfo for a PCFG-based TreeCRF parser.
Experiments showed that SemInfo has a strong sentence-level correlation with sentence-F1 and that SemInfo maintains a consistent corpus-level correlation throughout the PCFG training process.
The strong sentence-level correlation indicates that SemInfo can serve as an accurate metric of parsing accuracy.
The consistent corpus-level correlation indicates that SemInfo can serve as a reliable training objective for unsupervised parsing.
As a result, SemInfo-trained PCFGs significantly outperformed LL-trained PCFGs across four languages and achieved new state-of-the-art results in three of them.
Our findings underscore the effectiveness of leveraging semantic information in unsupervised constituency parsing, paving the way for accurate semantically-informed unsupervised parsing methods.
